headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: CORRECTIONS China’s Comac C919 jet is a competitor to Boeing 737. A Page One article on Wednesday about Boeing incorrectly identified the competing plane as the 747. Audi’s A7 is among models being recalled because of software problems.

raw.summary: CORRECTIONS China’s Comac C919 jet is a competitor to Boeing 737. A Page One article on Wednesday about Boeing incorrectly identified the competing plane as the 747. Audi’s A7 is among models being recalled because of software problems.

headline: United Airlines Says It's Unfazed by Tariffs’ Potential Impact
summary: United Airlines doesn’t expect tariffs to have a significant impact on what it pays for planes, Chief Executive Scott Kirby said.  Most of the aircraft deliveries United is waiting on will come from Boeing, and most of its new Airbus planes are being built in Alabama, though the network of suppliers that the plane makers rely on is spread throughout the world.  Rival Delta Air Lines said last week it won’t pay tariffs on any new Airbus planes coming its way and would defer any deliveries affected by new levies.

raw.headline: United Airlines Says It's Unfazed by Tariffs’ Potential Impact

Rival Delta Air Lines said last week it won’t pay tariffs on any new Airbus planes coming its way and would defer any deliveries affected by new levies.

headline: Well-Known Investor Says China News “Not Material” for Boeing (BA)
summary: After China reportedly decided that it would no longer accept deliveries of Boeing’s (BA) planes, prominent investor Stephanie Link yesterday said that the news was “clearly not material for Boeing at this time.” Link, who owns BA stock and has called the name her top pick for 2025, is the Chief Investment Strategist of Hightower […]

headline: Big banks report Q1 beats, China stops taking Boeing deliveries: Morning Buzz

headline: Boeing should be able to reallocate aircraft meant for China, says BofA
summary: BofA analyst Ronald Epstein notes Bloomberg’s report that China halted delivery of all Boeing (BA) jets and asked Chinese carriers to halt any purchases of aircraft-related equipment and parts from U.S. companies as part of the escalating trade war between the countries. Boeing is the largest U.S. exporter, so the firm is not surprised by China’s move, though it sees this situation as “unsustainable” given the firm’s view that Airbus (EADSY) can’t realistically be China’s only supplier of large
